The most demoralizing place I've ever worked at. No focus on innovation, growth, or change. Rather, the company is doubling down on tradition and history, stuck 50 years in the past. No sense of community because everyone is so overworked and underpaid. No cost of living raises in 10 years.

review_title: No shared governance, leadership largely concerned with empire building, quick to punish perceived enemies.
pros: President has finally been ousted, so it is possible that the school's original identity as a faith-based, liberal arts college will be resusitated. It was a great idea: combine liberal arts core with solid career and/or pre-professional preparation. Perhaps with  less ruthless implementation  of the expansion plan, a good school can become great. Many wonderful, student focused faculty. Motivated students, many the first in family to attend college. Lovely setting. Salary reasonably good.
cons: Tuition driven school, pressure to accept and retain students who don't meet criteria. Pressure to keep silent about ethical issues. Far flung campuses result in ridiculous driving times for many faculty. Any suggestion to increase the rigor of degree completion program met with this objection; "That will kill the cash cow!". Active attempts to hide information from accrediting bodies.

pros: Work-life balance;  nice Christian environment, great way to make friends with coworkers; Nice Christmas break
cons: Not paid enough; University does not offer many advancements; faculty are priority; Upper management does not appreciate staff ; too many duties
